2. Stir in the ginger and spices, and cook for another minute. 
Pour in the coconut milk and 100ml water, stir, then simmer for 10 mins.
3. Add the cod, frozen peas and sugar snap peas, and simmer for 5 mins until the fish is flaky.
4. Serve with the rice, sliced chilli, a good grinding of black pepper and some lime wedges on the side for squeezing over.

3 to 4 chicken backs
1 dozen large crabs
1 pouch crab boil mix
1 tablespoon salt and pepper
6 ounces tomato paste
1 pint canned chopped tomatoes
2 medium onions, diced
2 medium green peppers, diced
2 cups celery stalks, diced
4 cups chopped okra, more to taste
8 to 10 garlic cloves, finely chopped
1 1/2 cups shortening
2 cups all-purpose flour, or as needed
3 tablespoons granulated sugar
4 pounds raw shrimp, peeled, more to taste
1 pint shucked oysters
1 pint picked, cooked crab meat
2 teaspoons gumbo filé powder

1. In a large stock pot, place in the chicken backs and crabs. 
2. Cover with 1 1/2 gallons of water.
3. Add the crab boil mix and salt and pepper.
4. Bring mixture to a boil, lower heat, and stir in tomato paste and canned tomatoes.
5. Stir to dissolve the tomato paste. Add chopped vegetables and garlic to this mixture and continue to simmer while you prepare the roux.
6. In a large skillet, heat the shortening. When hot, adjust flame to medium-low.
7. Stir flour into shortening gradually, adding small amounts at a time and stirring constantly to mix in.
8. Use enough flour to take up the grease. Continue to brown the flour until it is a deep dark brown color.
9. Just before the roux reaches the ideal color, add in the sugar, cook and stir until the mixture becomes hard and hangs together when you lift spoon. Let cool slightly.
10. Add roux to the liquid crab mixture, stirring to mix well. 
11. Let it come to a boil, then lower the heat and add the shrimp, oysters, and crab meat.
12. Let this mixture cook for about 10 minutes. Adjust salt and seasonings, if necessary, then adjust heat so that the pot is simmering and add the filé. Let gumbo simmer on very low heat  until ready to serve.
13. Serve in bowls over hot cooked rice.

1 small shallot, finely chopped
2 tablespoons fresh parsley, finely chopped
1 tablespoon fresh chives, finely chopped
1 egg
2 tablespoons mayonnaise
2 teaspoons dijon mustard
2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice
½ teaspoon worcestershire sauce
1 pinch cayenne pepper, optional
1 lb fresh lump crab meat (455 g), picked over
fine sea salt
freshly ground black pepper
1 cup panko breadcrumbs (50 g)
2 tablespoons all purpose flour, for dusing
2 tablespoons unsalted butter
tartar sauce, recipe follows
lemon wedge

1. In a large bowl, whisk together the shallot, parsley, chives, egg, mayonnaise, Dijon mustard, lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce, and cayenne if using.
2. Add the crabmeat, season with salt and pepper and stir to combine.
3. Add the breadcrumbs and mix just to combine.
4. Form into 6 equal patties and place on a plate. Chill in the refrigerator for at least 15 minutes, up to 1 hour.
5. Coat the cakes lightly with flour, and shake off any excess.
6. In a large skillet set over medium heat, melt the butter.
7. Fry the crab cakes until golden and crisp, 3-4 minutes per side. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate to drain slightly.
8. Serve warm with tartar sauce and lemon wedges.
9. Enjoy!

1 lb large shrimp (455 g), peeled and deveined
3 cloves garlic, minced
2 cups broccoli floret (500 g)
½ onion, diced
1 tablespoon low sodium soy sauce
2 tablespoons sesame oil, divided
½ teaspoon salt, divided

1. Heat 1 tablespoon of sesame oil in a large, nonstick skillet over medium heat.
2. Pour in the shrimp and season with ¼ teaspoon of the salt.
3. Fry the shrimp for 1 minute on each side.
4. Remove the shrimp from the pan and pour in the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil.
5. Toss in the onion and remaining ¼ teaspoon of salt and sauté for a few minutes until they begin to soften.
6. Add in the broccoli, garlic and soy sauce and sauté until the garlic is fragrant, about 30 seconds.
7. Toss the shrimp back into the pan and mix until everything is well incorporated and the shrimp is fully cooked, about 1 minute.
8. Divide the mixture evenly between 4 bowls.
9. Enjoy!

2 cups short grain rice (400 g)
5 chicken breasts, medium-sized
4 cups hot chicken broth (960 mL)
½ cup chorizo crumbles (95 g)
12 jumbo shrimps
1 tablespoon olive oil
⅓ cup onion (50 g), diced
⅓ cup diced tomato (65 g)
1 teaspoon smoked paprika
1 teaspoon salt
1 teaspoon pepper
1 teaspoon garlic powder
1 small bay leaf
1 pinch saffron
fresh cilantro, as garnish

1. Heat 1 tbsp olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Then, saute chorizo crumbles and set aside.
2. In the same pan, brown chicken and set aside once cooked through and golden brown.
3. In the same pan (without draining the oil), add onions and tomatoes and sprinkle smoked paprika. Saute until translucent.
4. Next, add short grain rice, chicken broth, small bay leaf, salt, pepper, garlic powder, and saffron. Mix well.
5. Once broth reduces by half, add chicken atop rice and layer with sliced red peppers. Cover pot, reduce heat to low, and cook for 20 minutes.
6. Then, add shrimp into the pan, cover, and cook until pink.
7. Serve warm, garnished with cilantro and lemon.

25g butter
2 tbsp olive oil
3 garlic cloves, finely chopped
1 red chilli, seeds left in and finely chopped
½ tsp sweet paprika
12-20 large raw king prawns with shells
juice 1 lemon, plus a few slices for a finger bowl
½ x small bunch parsley, roughly chopped
small loaf crusty bread, warmed to serve

1. Melt the butter and oil together in a frying pan. 
2. Add the garlic, chilli and paprika, then fry for 1-2 mins until starting to turn golden.
3. Turn up the heat, throw in the prawns and fry for a few mins, stirring, until all the prawns turn pink.
4. Take off the heat, season and stir in the lemon juice and parsley.
5. Add some lemon slices to a finger bowl of warm water, grab a bowl for the shells, then dig straight in with your fingers and hunks of crusty bread.

1 cup plain flour
1 cup cornflour
2 eggs, beaten lightly
1 1/2 cup (375ml) water
1 cup packaged breadcrumbs
500 gram mozzarella
vegetable oil, for deep-frying
1/3 cup sun-dried tomato pesto
2/3 cup sweet chilli sauce

1. Whisk flour, cornflour, egg and the water in medium bowl until smooth, place breadcrumbs in small bowl.
2. Cut cheese into 1cm-wide fingers.
3. Dip cheese sticks, one at a time, in batter, then in breadcrumbs to coat.
4. Dip cheese sticks, one at a time, back in batter, then in breadcrumbs to double-coat.
5. Heat oil in large saucepan, deep-fry cheese sticks, in batches, until golden brown, drain on absorbent paper.
6. Make the chilli pesto dipping sauce.
7. Combine pesto and sauce in small bowl.
8. Serve hot with chilli pesto dipping sauce.

1/2 cup smooth peanut butter
1 tbsp peanut or vegetable oil
2 cups julienned Chinese barbecued pork
10 cups shredded green cabbage (about 1 large cabbage), blanched, squeezed dry in a dish towel
1/2 cup chopped green onions
2 tsp sugar
2 tsp salt
1/2 tsp freshly ground pepper
1/4 tsp cinnamon

1. Mix the pork, the cabbage, the onions, the sugar, the salt, the pepper, the cinnamon, and any of the extra ingredients, if desired, in a large bowl.
2. Warm the peanut butter over low heat until pourable. Add a tablespoon of peanut oil if necessary to get the right texture. Wait until it cools a bit, then pour it into the bowl with ingredients and mix until well combined.
3. Slice off 1-inch from the corners of each wrapper. Stack the wrappers, then place them in front of you, so that a corner is pointing towards you.
4. Place ¼ cup of the filling near the corner closest to you, then roll upwards. When you reach the middle part of the wrapper, fold the sides inward, and continue rolling until there are only 2 inches of the wrapper remaining. Brush with egg white and seal. 
5. Fry the rolls in batches, in 350°F oil or lard, until golden. Transfer on paper towel-lined plates to drain.
6. Serve hot, with a side of either, duck sauce, sweet and sour sauce, or hot mustard for dipping.

1 pound dried chickpeas
6 cloves of garlic, crushed and roughly minced
1 medium yellow onion, quartered and roughly chopped
3/4 cup parsley leaves, chopped
3/4 cup cilantro, chopped
1 1/2 teaspoons ground coriander
1 tablespoon ground cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt
3/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
1 teaspoon baking soda
2 tablespoons freshly squeezed lemon juice
1 tablespoon lemon zest
Neutral-tasting oil, for frying

1. Place chickpeas in a large pot and cover with several inches of water.Bring to a simmer, turn off the heat, give the chickpeas a stir, and let sit at least overnight.
2. Remove some of the cooking liquid from the chickpeas and reserve. Drain them well, then place in a bowl of a large food processor.
3. To the chickpeas, add the garlic, onion, parsley, and cilantro. In a small bowl, stir together the coriander, cumin, cayenne, salt, pepper, and baking soda, then add it to the chickpeas along with the lemon juice and zest.
4. Pulse the whole mixture several times until the chickpeas are broken down and resemble chopped nuts. Scrape down the sides of the food processor, then re-pulse as necessary.
5. If the mixture is too dry to hold together when pressed, add some of the reserved liquid, a little at a time. Pour the mixture into a large bowl and give it a few good stirs to make sure everything is incorporated.
6. Scoop up the mixture in rounded tablespoons, roll into balls, and flatten slightly. Set aside on a baking sheet.
7. Heat at least 2 inches of oil in a large, deep stockpot over medium-high heat.
8. When the oil reaches about 350º F, carefully slip in several of the falafel, making sure not to crowd the pan. Fry the falafel until they reach a deep golden brown -- it should only take a few minutes.
9. When they're done, transfer them onto paper towels to drain. Repeat with the rest of the falafel. Serve hot or at room temperature.

2 medium tomatoes (300g), seeded, chopped finely
1/2 small red onion (50g), chopped finely
1 clove garlic, crushed
1 tablespoon red wine vinegar
2 tablespoon olive oil
4 slice sourdough bread (280g)
cooking-oil spray
2 tablespoon finely shredded fresh basil

1. Preheat oven to 220°C/425°F.
2. Combine tomato, onion, garlic, vinegar and oil in small bowl.
3. Stand 20 minutes.
4. Meanwhile, place bread on oiled oven tray, spray with cooking oil. 
5. Toast, in oven (or under grill), until browned both sides.
6. Stir basil into tomato mixture, spoon onto toasted bread.

1 package frozen puff pastry
3/4 cup grated, aged goat cheese
8 ounces soft-ripened goat cheese
1 bunch asparagus
Freshly ground pepper and sea salt, to taste

1. Preheat your oven to 400 °F.
2. Piece together two rectangles of puff pastry by overlapping them. Roll up the edges until they're about 1/2 inch high.
3. Sprinkle the aged goat cheese over the puff pastry in a thin layer.
4. Halve the soft-rind goat cheese log, and then slice lengthwise into 1 inch strips. Layer on the strips intermittently in three rows.
5. Snap the asparagus into shorter pieces when necessary.
6. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes, until puff pastry is golden.
7. Serve hot or at room temperature.

400g pack frozen pollock fillets, thawed, dried and roughly chopped
1 egg
1 tbsp red Thai curry paste
2 tsp fish sauce
1 tbsp cornflour
zest and juice 1 lime
50g green beans, trimmed and finely sliced
2 tbsp sunflower oil, for frying
3 tbsp sweet chilli dipping sauce

1. Tip the fish into a food processor with the egg, curry paste, fish sauce and cornflour, then blitz until smooth. 
2. Tip the mixture into a bowl and stir in the lime zest and green beans, then shape into 8 fish cakes.
3. Heat a little oil in a large non-stick frying pan, then cook the fish cakes for a couple of mins each side until firm and cooked through.
4. While the fish cakes are cooking, stir the lime juice into the chilli sauce to make a dressing. 
5. Pile salad onto plates, top with the fish cakes and drizzle with a little dressing.

85g cornflour
85g plain flour
2 tsp black pepper, cracked
2 tbsp ground Szechuan peppercorns, roughly crushed
sunflower or vegetable oil, for frying
400g squid, cleaned and cut into strips
finely sliced spring onion and green chilli, to serve
1 red chilli, finely chopped
half cucumber, finely diced
1 small red onion, finely chopped
100ml rice wine vinegar
1 tbsp caster sugar
2 tsp fish sauce

1. To make the dipping sauce, mix all the ingredients in a small bowl until the sugar has dissolved, then set aside. 
2. Mix the cornflour and plain flour with both peppers and 2 tsp sea salt in a large bowl, then set aside.
3. Line a tray with kitchen paper and make sure you have more salt to sprinkle with.
4. Heat about 7cm of oil to 180C in a deep fryer, wok or deep pan. 
5. Coat the squid well with the flour mix and fry in batches for about 2 mins each or until crisp. 
6. Use a slotted spoon to lift out the squid, then drain on the kitchen paper and sprinkle with a little more salt. 
7. Serve the squid scattered with the spring onion and chilli, with the dipping sauce on the side.

1 lb sea scallop (455 g), side muscles removed
fine sea salt
black pepper, freshly ground
1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil
2 tablespoons unsalted butter, cut into small pieces
1 clove garlic, grated
1 tablespoon dry white wine
2 tablespoons fresh chives, finely chopped

1. Pat the scallops dry with a paper towel.
2. Season with salt and pepper.
3. In a large skillet set over medium-high heat, add the oil.
4. When the oil is hot, add the scallops and cook until golden brown on one side, 2-3 minutes.
5. Gently turn the scallops, and add the butter and garlic to the pan.
6. Continue to cook, spooning the butter over the scallops until they are cooked through, about 3 minutes more.
7. Add the white wine, cook another 10 seconds.
8. Serve with chives.
9. Enjoy!

2 cups dry white wine
1/2 cup Minced Shallots
8 sprigs Fresh tarragon minced
1/4 Fresh thymes
1/8 tablespoon Fresh cracked black pepper
5 tablespoons Butter
7 quarts Mussels scrubbed, and soaked
2 tablespoons Chili pepper crushed
1/2 cup Fresh parsley diced
2 splashes White truffle oil

1. Bring all but the last three ingredients to boil in the kettle. Boil for 2 to 3 minutes to evaporate its alcohol and to reduce its volume slightly.
2. Add the mussels to the kettle. Cover tightly and boil quickly over high heat.
3. In about 5 minutes, the shells will swing open and the mussels are done.
4. With a big skimmer, dip the mussels into wide soup places.
5. Allow the cooking liquid to settle for a moment so any sand will sink to the bottom.
6. Then ladle the liquid over the mussels, sprinkle with the parsley and splash of white truffle oil, serve immediately.

12 thin slices of smoked salmon
2 green apples, peeled and cored
Red peppercorns
Fresh dill
1 lemon
2 Chicory heads
1 cup yoghurt
3 teaspoons Dijon mustard
3 teaspoons honey
2 teaspoons grated fresh ginger
1 tablespoon fresh dill removed from stalk
Extra dill for decorating
1/2 cup Greek yoghurt for decorating

1. Sauce Put all the ingredients in a bowl and mix very well.
2. Dice the peeled and cored apple in very small cubes, about 0.2 inches. Add them immediately to the sauce and toss to coat.
3. Cut the slices of salmon in strips.
4. Finger food version Put some apple tartare in a leaf, add some cut up smoked salmon on top, a teaspoon of plain Greek yoghurt and a small sprig of dill. Add a wedge of lemon, red peppercorns and serve.

1 cup shredded carrots
3 cups broccoli florets
1 garlic clove
2 eggs
1 1/4 cups seasoned breadcrumbs, divided
3/4 cup shredded cheddar cheese
1/2 teaspoon onion powder
1/2 teaspoon black pepper
1 tablespoon canola oil

1. Shred carrots.
2. Steam broccoli in the microwave for two minutes or until tender.
3. Place shredded carrots, steamed broccoli, garlic, eggs,1 cup of the breadcrumbs, cheese, onion powder, and black pepper in food processor and pulse for 15 seconds or until well combined. 
4. Form mixture into balls, about a tablespoon each 
5. Place remaining 1/4 cup breadcrumbs in a shallow dish. Coat each veggie nuggets with breadcrumbs.
6. Heat oil in a skillet on medium high heat until it sizzles when sprinkled with water droplets.
7. Arrange nuggets in skillet and cook about 4 minutes each side, or until golden brown and crispy. 
8. Serve with honey-mustard sauce, ketchup, or other favorite dip.

1 small shallot, finely chopped
2 tablespoons fresh parsley, finely chopped
1 tablespoon fresh chives, finely chopped
1 egg
2 tablespoons mayonnaise
2 teaspoons dijon mustard
2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice
½ teaspoon worcestershire sauce
1 pinch cayenne pepper, optional
1 lb fresh lump crab meat (455 g), picked over
fine sea salt
freshly ground black pepper
1 cup panko breadcrumbs (50 g)
2 tablespoons all purpose flour, for dusing
2 tablespoons unsalted butter

1. In a large bowl, whisk together the shallot, parsley, chives, egg, mayonnaise, Dijon mustard, lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce, and cayenne if using.
2. Add the crabmeat, season with salt and pepper and stir to combine.
3. Add the breadcrumbs and mix just to combine.
4. Form into 6 equal patties and place on a plate. Chill in the refrigerator for at least 15 minutes, up to 1 hour.
5. Coat the cakes lightly with flour, and shake off any excess.
6. In a large skillet set over medium heat, melt the butter.
7. Fry the crab cakes until golden and crisp, 3-4 minutes per side. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate to drain slightly.
8. Enjoy!

4 cups mixed olives
2 sprigs thyme
Peel of 1 orange
1 tablespoon toasted coriander seeds
1/2 tablespoon toasted cumin seeds
1 small dried chili, crumbled
1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil

1. Mix the spices and the olives together and cover with olive oil.
2. Let macerate at room temperature for a minimum of one hour.
3. These olives will also keep for at least week in the fridge.

1 cup flour (125 g)
1 teaspoon chili powder
1 teaspoon kosher salt
1 teaspoon black pepper, freshly ground
1 teaspoon paprika
1 teaspoon garlic powder
20 chicken wings, or drumettes
1 cup BBQ sauce (290 g)

1. In a bowl, combine flour, chili powder, salt, pepper, paprika, and garlic powder. Coat the wings in the flour evenly, shaking off any excess.
2. Place the floured wings on a parchment paper–lined baking sheet and spread them out in a single layer.
3. Bake for 45 minutes, flipping halfway through, until skin is crispy and golden brown.
4. In a separate bowl, combine the BBQ sauce. Stir the cooked wings in the sauce and coat them evenly.
5. Place the coated wings back onto the baking sheet and spread them in a single layer.
6. Bake for 8 to 10 minutes, until sauce is bubbly and caramelized. Cool, then serve.
7. Enjoy!

2 kg game meat (deer or wild boar) boneless
2 shallots
1 carrot
12 juniper berries
1 l dry white wine
3 tbsp of Armagnac
1 bouquet garni
2 slices of bacon
350 g sausage meat
200 g ground veal
salt
pepper

1. Cut the game meat into thin strips. Peel and chop the shallots. Peel the carrot and cut into slices. Crush 12 juniper berries.
2. Put the meat in a terrine mold with the spices, berries, and root vegetables. Add the white wine, three tablespoons of Armagnac and bouquet garni. Stir and leave to marinate for 24 hours in a cool place.
3. The next day, first, preheat the oven to 180°C. Drain the pieces of meat and pat them dry.
4. Spread a slice of bacon in the bottom of a terrine mold, Cover with strips of game meat, then a layer of sausage meat and veal. Add salt and pepper. Place the second slice of bacon on top to seal.
5. Cover the terrine with a lid, place it in a water bath, and cook in the oven for two hours. After cooking, remove the lid and allow to cool.
6. Serve cold the next day as a starter.

DOUGH
1 cup warm water (235 mL)
2 tablespoons olive oil
2 tablespoons honey
2 teaspoons salt
3 ⅓ cups flour (415 g)
1 ½ teaspoons yeast

TOPPINGS
2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
2 sprigs fresh rosemary, leaves removed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste

1. Combine water, olive oil, honey, salt, flour, and yeast in a large bowl.
2. Mix well and knead for 10-15 minutes until the dough is elastic.
Transfer the dough into a well-oiled bowl.
3. Cover with a towel or plastic wrap and let rise once for 1 hour in a warm place, until the dough has doubled.
4. Remove the dough from the bowl and stretch the dough into 9-inch (23 cm) circle.
5. Place the dough into well greased 10-inch (25 cm) cast iron pan. Cover with towel or plastic wrap and rest for 30 minutes.
6. Poke the top with your fingertips.
7. Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle with rosemary, salt, and pepper.
8. Bake in the oven for 20-30 minutes.
9. Slice and serve.
10. Enjoy!

1 tablespoon vegetable oil
1 medium_piece brown onion, finely chopped
3 slice white bread
350 gram (11 ounces) sausage mince
350 gram (11 ounces) minced (ground) beef
1 tablespoon tomato paste
1 teaspoon dried mixed herbs
2 tablespoon fresh flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped

1. Heat vegetable oil in small frying pan, cook finely chopped brown onion. 
2. Cut crusts off 3 slices white bread.
3. Discard crusts.
4. Dip bread in small bowl of cold water, remove immediately.
5. Combine onion and bread in large bowl with sausage mince, ground beef, tomato paste, dried mixed herbs and finely chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley.
6. Preheat oven to 220°C.
7. Lightly oil two oven trays.
8. Cut 4 sheets puff pastry in half lengthways.
9. Place equal amounts of mixture lengthways along centre of each pastry piece, roll each pastry piece, from one wide edge, to enclose filling. 
10. Place four rolls, seam-side down, on each of the prepared trays; brush with lightly beaten egg. Sprinkle with sesame seeds, cut each roll into eight pieces.
11. Bake, uncovered, about 15 minutes.

12 mini sausages
6 rashers bacon
1 cup grated mozzarella cheese (100 g)
1 sheet puff pastry
egg wash, as needed
2 tablespoons black onion seed, to taste

1. Cut the rashers in half lengthwise, and roll the sausages in them. Set aside.
2. Lay out the sheet of puff pastry and coat with some egg wash.
Cut into 12 squares.
3. In each square, sprinkle on some cheese, followed by a sausage wrapped in bacon.
4. Roll in the pastry. Pierce some holes on top of each roll and coat with more egg wash. Top with black onion seeds.
5. Bake for 20 minutes, or until golden brown and the sausages are cooked through.
6. Enjoy!

6 large mild onions
100g flour
1/4 cup cream
pepper
salt
3 eggs
1/4 lb parmesan cheese
lard, for frying
melted butter with mustard, for serving

1. Peel the onions, remove their top and bottom, and cut them into 1/2-inch-thick slices.
2. Prepare the batter by mixing flour, cream, salt, pepper, and eggs for 10 minutes.
3. Grate the parmesan cheese finely and add it to the batter. Mix well.
4. Heat lard for frying in a large pan.
5. Dip the onions in the batter so they are fully covered. Take them out using a fork, and fry in lard until they are brown and crispy.
6. Drain the onion rings on a paper towel.
7. Serve hot, with some melted butter with mustard.

3 cups stone-ground cornmeal
2 tsp kosher salt
2 tsp baking powder
3/4 tsp baking soda
3 tsp sugar (optional)
2 ½ cups buttermilk
3 eggs
1 ½ sticks of unsalted butter, melted, divided

1. Set the oven to preheat to 375°F, then place a well-seasoned, 12-inch cast iron skilled on the middle rack of the oven.
2. Next, add cornmeal, salt, baking powder, baking soda, and sugar if you’re using it to a large bowl, then whisk to combine.
3. Take a separate bowl, add to it buttermilk and eggs and while continuously whisking, drizzle in all of the melted butter in, except for one tablespoon.
4. Pour the liquid ingredients into the dry ones, and whisk just until combined. Don’t overmix, a few lumps here and there are perfectly fine.
5. Add the remaining tablespoon of melted to the now preheated skillet, swirling the skillet, so the bottom and the sides are coated. Scrape the batter into the skillet, and use a rubber spatula to smooth the top.
6. Place in the preheated oven and bake for 45 minutes or until the top turn lightly brown and a skewer inserted into the center comes out clean.
7. When done, leave the cornbread to cool in the skillet for 15 minutes, then serve while still warm.

1/2 cup plain low-fat yogurt
1/4 cup mayonnaise
3 tablespoons apple cider vinegar
1 tablespoon honey
1 teaspoon kosher salt
1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
8 cups very thinly sliced green cabbage (from 1 medium cabbage)
1/2 cup coarsely grated carrot (1 medium carrot)
1/4 cup thinly sliced red onion

1. In a large bowl, whisk together the yogurt, mayonnaise, vinegar, honey, salt and pepper.
2. Add the cabbage, carrot, onion and toss well to combine.
3. Cover and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes and up to overnight, so the cabbage softens a bit. 
4. Toss well before serving.

375 gram small shell pasta
1/4 cup fresh oregano, coarsely chopped
1/2 cup (125ml) olive oil
1/4 cup (60ml) lemon juice
3 cup (480g) shredded cooked chicken
1 medium_piece (170g) red onion, sliced thinly
500 gram cherry tomatoes, quartered
2 (260g) cucumbers, chopped coarsely
1 large_piece (350g) green capsicum, chopped coarsely
1 cup (120g) seeded kalamata olives
280 gram jar marinated artichoke hearts, drained, chopped coarsely
200 gram fetta cheese, chopped coarsely

1. Cook pasta in large saucepan of boiling water, uncovered, until just tender, drain. Rinse under cold water, drain.
2. Meanwhile, place 2 tablespoons of the oregano, oil and juice in a screw-top jar, shake well.
3. Place pasta in large bowl with chicken, onion, tomato, cucumber, capsicum, olives, artichoke, cheese and dressing, toss gently to combine.
4. Top salad with remaining oregano.

cooking-oil spray
2 (1kg) eggplants, cut into 1cm slices
2 (440g) tomatoes, finely chopped
1 cup coarsely chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley
1/2 cup (140g) low-fat natural yoghurt
2 tablespoon water
1 tablespoon mint sauce
1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh mint

1. Spray heated barbecue grill plate (or grill or barbecue) with cooking-oil spray.
2. Cook eggplant, about 2 minutes each side, until tender.
3. Make mint yoghurt dressing by combining yoghurt, water, mint sauce and mint in a small bowl.
4. Divide eggplant, tomato and parsley among plates; drizzle with dressing.

16-20 asparagus spears
2 tbsp sesame oil
1 tbsp soy sauce
1 garlic clove, crushed
2 tbsp sesame seeds

1. Place 4 or 5 asparagus stalks next to one another. 
2. Skewer them crosswise in two places – just below the tips and 3cm from the bottom – with slender bamboo skewers. 
3. In a small bowl, combine the sesame oil, soy sauce, garlic and sesame seeds and stir with a fork to mix.Brush this mixture on the asparagus rafts on both sides. 
4. Season the asparagus with a little salt and lots of pepper.
5. Grill the asparagus on a barbecue or in a griddle pan for 4-5 mins per side, turning with tongs. 
6. Sprinkle with sesame mix as they grill.

25g butter
1 small onion, finely chopped
2 tbsp plain flour
200ml full-fat milk
2 x 200g bags spinach
100ml single cream
fresh nutmeg, for grating

1. Heat the butter in a saucepan, then add the onion and cook for 5 mins until softened. 
2. Stir in the flour and cook for 2 mins, then slowly start to whisk in the milk. 
3. When it has all been incorporated, gently cook for 5 mins until the sauce has thickened.
4. Place the spinach in a large colander.
5. Pour over a kettle full of boiling water until the leaves have wilted.
6. Place the spinach in a clean dishcloth, squeeze out any excess liquid, then roughly chop. 
7. Stir into the sauce with the cream, gently heat, then finely grate over some nutmeg and season well.

2 (400g) medium potatoes, coarsely chopped
2 (240g) medium carrots, coarsely chopped
1 (200g) large brown onion, coarsely chopped
1 (150g) medium tomato, coarsely chopped
1 (150g) stalk celery, trimmed, coarsely chopped
6 cup (1.5l) water
1 tablespoon olive oil
50 gram butter
4 (800g) medium potatoes, extra, coarsely chopped
1 (500g) large leek, thickly sliced
300 millilitre cream
2 tablespoon finely chopped fresh chives
1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh basil
1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh dill

1. In large saucepan, bring potato, carrot, onion, tomato, celery and the water to the boil. Reduce heat, simmer, uncovered, 20 minutes.
2. Strain broth through muslin-lined sieve or colander into large heatproof bowl, set aside solids.
3. In same cleaned pan, heat oil and butter.
4. Cook extra potato and leek, covered, 15 minutes, stirring occasionally.
5. Add broth, bring to the boil.
6. Reduce heat, simmer, covered, 15 minutes.
7. Cool 15 minutes.
8. Blend or process soup, in batches, until smooth.
9. Return soup to same cleaned pan.
10. Add cream, stir over medium heat until hot.
11. Serve bowls of soup sprinkled with combined herbs and croutons if desired.

2 tablespoons olive oil
1 large onion, diced
2 ribs celery, diced (1/2 cup)
1 large carrot, scrubbed well, then diced
1 medium red bell pepper, seeded and diced
1 medium zucchini (about 8 ounces), diced
4 cloves garlic, minced
1 teaspoon dried oregano
1 teaspoon dried basil
1 teaspoon kosher salt
1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
28 ounces canned, no-salt-added crushed tomatoes
48 ounces (6 cups) no-salt-added vegetable broth or chicken broth
15 ounces canned, no-salt-added small red beans, drained and rinsed
1/2 cup dried, whole-grain elbow pasta
1/3 cup freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, for garnish

1. Heat the oil in a large soup pot over medium heat. 
2. Once the oil shimmers, add the onion, celery, carrot and bell pepper; cook for about 6 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they begin to soften.
3. Add the zucchini, garlic, oregano, basil, salt and pepper, cook, stirring, for 2 minutes. 
4. Add the tomatoes and broth, bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to medium-low.
5. Partially cover and cook for 10 minutes, stirring once or twice, then add the beans and pasta.
6. Increase the heat to medium-high just long enough to return the soup to a boil, then reduce the heat to medium-low and cook uncovered for 10 to 15 minutes, until the pasta and vegetables are tender.
7. Garnish each portion with the cheese.

1 lb lean ground beef (454 g)
1 small onion, chopped
15 oz canned kidney bean (425 g), 1 can
15 oz canned black bean (425 g), 1 can
15 oz canned corn kernels (425 g), 1 can
15 oz canned diced tomato (425 g), 1 can
8 oz tomato sauce (225 g), 1 can
2 tablespoons taco seasoning
1 shredded cheddar cheese, to serve
1 sour cream, to serve
1 pico de gallo, to serve
1 avocado, sliced, to serve
1 tortilla chip, to serve
1 lime wedge, to serve
1 chopped cilantro, to serve

1. Add the ground beef and onion to a large pot and stir until the beef is cooked through.
2. Drain excess liquid.
3. Add the kidney beans, black beans, corn, tomatoes, tomato sauce, and taco seasoning to the pot, and stir until combined.
4. Cook over medium heat for 10 minutes.
5. Serve with cheddar cheese, sour cream, pico de gallo, avocado, corn chips, lime wedges, and cilantro.
6. Enjoy!

1 tablespoon olive oil
1 large onion, chopped (about 2 cups)
2 cloves garlic, minced (about 2 teaspoons)
One 2 ½-pound butternut squash, peeled, seeded, and cut into 1-inch cubes
6 cups low-sodium chicken or vegetable broth
½ teaspoon salt, plus more to taste
2 tablespoons honey
4 teaspoons plain nonfat yogurt, for garnish

1. Heat the oil over medium heat in a large soup pot. 
2. Add the onion and garlic and cook, stirring until softened, about 5 minutes. 
3. Add the squash, broth and salt and bring to a boil. 
4. Reduce the heat to a medium-low and simmer until the squash is tender, about 15 minutes. 
5. Remove the soup from the heat, stir in the honey, and puree until smooth in the pot using an immersion blender or in two batches in a regular blender. 
6. Taste and season with salt, if necessary.
7. Ladle the soup into serving bowls and drizzle with the yogurt

1 kilogram pumpkin, peeled and chopped
1 large potato, peeled and chopped
1 large onion, finely chopped
1 clove garlic, finely chopped
4 cups water
3 teaspoons vegetable (or chicken) stock powder
1 tin spiced tomatoes

1. Add onion and garlic to pot with a little oil. Fry until onion is cooked.
2. Add pumpkin, potato, water and stock powder.
3. Bring to the boil and simmer for about 15 to 20 minutes or until vegetables are very soft and mushy.
4. Remove soup from heat.
5. Add tomatoes.
6. Puree soup with stick blender, mash with a potato masher, or blend in a food processor.
7. If necessary, reheat before serving.
8. Serve with toasted wholegrain bread.

PASTRY DOUGH
2 ½ cups (300g) all-purpose flour, plus extra for work surface
2 tbsp granulated sugar
1 tsp kosher or sea salt
18 tbsp (2-1/4 sticks) chilled unsalted butter, cut into small cubes
6-8 tbsp ice water

FILLING
5 cups (1 kg) fresh wild blueberries
3 tbsp flour
1/2 cup (100g) sugar
1/2-1 tsp lemon juice
1 ½ tbsp butter
1 egg, beaten, for glaze

1. First, prepare the pastry for the pie. In a medium-sized bowl, add flour, salt, and sugar, then mix until combined. Next, add butter, and using your fingers, rub it in into the flour mixture until it starts looking like breadcrumbs.
2. Add six tablespoons of ice water and stir using a fork until it forms into a dough.
3. Transfer to a lightly floured surface and knead only three times, then gather into a ball. Divide the dough into two pieces, a slightly larger and a smaller piece.
4. Flatten each piece into a disk, then wrap in cling film and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
5. To make the pie, first, set the oven to preheat to 400°F/200°C.
6. Toss the blueberries with flour, sugar, and lemon juice and set aside.
7. Take a large piece of the pastry dough, place it between two sheets of baking paper, and roll it out into a 13-inch (33cm) circle.
8. Remove the top sheet of baking paper from the dough, place the dough paper-free side down into a 9-inch (23cm) deep-dish pie pan, then remove the remaining baking paper.
9. Press the dough into the pie pan and leave any excess dough to overhang.
10. Repeat the same with the smaller disk of dough, only roll it to an 11-inch (28cm) circle, and leave aside for later.
11. Pour the berries into the pie crust and top with pieces of butter.
12. Take the smaller circle of dough, remove the baking paper, and place the baking paper side on top, then also peel off that remaining sheet of baking paper.
13. With a knife, make three slits in the top crust for steam to escape.
14. Next, fold the bottom pie crust over the top and crimp together at the edges to seal.
15. Glaze with an egg wash.
16. Bake for 45-50 minutes.

1 (9-inch/23cm) unbaked or frozen deep-dish pie crust
1 cup (330g) corn syrup
3 eggs
1 cup (200g) sugar
2 tbsp butter, melted
1 ½ cup (190g) pecans
1 tsp vanilla extract

1. Set the oven to preheat to 350°F/180°C. Lightly coat the pie pan with oil and place the pie crust.
2. Next, combine corn syrup, eggs, sugar, butter, and vanilla, then add the pecans.
3. Pour the filling into the pie crust and bake in the oven for 60 to 70 minutes.
4. Once baked, cool for two hours before serving.

1 tablespoon vanilla extract
1 can sweetened condensed milk
2 cans evaporated milk
2 cups white sugar
4 eggs
 whole milk
 salt
 ice
 fruit (optional)

1. With an electric mixer, cream eggs and sugar.
2. Add evaporated milk, condensed milk, and vanilla. Beat well. 
3. Pour into an electric ice cream churn. 
4. Add whole milk to fill line. Insert dasher.
5. Pack cooler 1/3 full with ice. Add a layer of rock salt. Repeat layering with ice and salt until full.
6. Note: be careful not to overfill, spilling salt into the churn. 
7. When machine starts to labor or shut off, remove the dasher and drain water. 
8. Fill with more ice and salt. 
9. Cover with a towel and let harden. Makes about 1 gallon.
